title: From Surgeon to Biotech CEO with Jonathan Lim

rawLines.text: [Music]
[Music]
I am thrilled today to be hosting
Jonathan Lim, the CEO of Arasa.
Jonathan, thank you for being here
today. Thanks, Jorge. It's awesome to be
here. Why don't we start at the sort of
at the top here, which is on you and
your background. So, you are the CEO of
Arasa. you didn't start out on the
business side. Uh by background, you're
a physician and if memory serves, you
were a surgeon. So, walk me through the
the sort of the trip from the operating
room to the boardroom. Yeah. I grew up
in San Diego just loving the movies and
thinking maybe I'll be a filmmaker one
day, but I also love science and wanted
to be a doctor and really use science to
help people. So I was premed at
Stanford, went to back to Montreal where
I was born and then uh went to McGill
and then went straight into general
surgery at New York Hospital and and I
just loved it. So I was a really happy
surgeon. Uh but I did a two-year uh
break in Boston and I worked at Dana
Farber Cancer Institute. So I did some
cancer epidemiology research. Then I
also did an M. PH in healthcare
management at Harvard School of Public
Health. So that was my period of
exploration. And during that time I
really uh decided, wow, entrepreneurship
looks really cool. So I went to McKenzie
for a couple years. Oh man. And then uh
down the dark path came entered the dark
side and then I uh uh joined Halo when
they were a fourperson startup in 2003.
A couple of interesting jumps in what
you just described being a practicing
surgeon to a McKenzie. It seems like a
leap, but in some ways those are pretty
safe bets, right? From there though,
McKenzie to a four-person startup. Talk
to me about that leap because that seems
like uh the riskiest of the leaps from
what you've described. I'm a big
believer in that that things happen for
a reason. Uh you know based on my own uh
Christian faith and other things, but my
my dad introduced me to one of his
patients who had a uh a venture capital
startup and uh her name's Audrey Vurby.
I um met her and she saw my background
in surgery and McKenzie and she thought,
"Hey, you could be a CEO in biotech."
And I thought she was joking, but then I
got a call just a couple months later
saying, "Hey, do you want to move to San
Diego?" I said, "Why?" And she said,
"Uh, we have this biotech startup that
we'd like you to run." And so I was Wow.
You got called in as the CEO. I got
called in as a CEO. So I was 31 at the
time. I knew nothing. I mean, I knew a
little bit about biotech cuz at
McKenzie, I I served a broad range of of
clients across healthcare. Uh, but I
mean, this was totally a leap of faith.
And, uh, I was employee number five. Um,
I didn't know what questions to ask. I
didn't know what I didn't know. So, we
had three months of cash on hand, a
company that had zero uh, VC dollars
invested. And, uh, we said, well, how do
we go public? And so the idea of a
reverse merger of Halo I'm the private
company merging with a public shell
company. So we were on the
over-the-counter bulletin boards and we
uh traded for for a few months. Uh let's
see we uplisted to the American Stock
Exchange about a year later and then to
the NASDAQ two and a half years later
and the rest is history. So yeah really
humble origins. Wow. Yeah. And what what
was the stage of the company when you
did this? We were pre-clinical. So
pre-clinical company 2003 this was on
enhanced technology I mean the
technology itself we knew it would work
but it's just we needed people to
believe in it and so uh we were able to
then um really derisk the uh technology
and and uh we signed a deal with with RO
so they took a leap of faith where we
got that deal done in 30 days at the end
of 2006. Wow. And then we became uh the
fourth performing stock uh on the in the
Wall Street Journal that year and it was
just amazing like all of a sudden we
were on people's radars and we struck
deals with with Roge and Baxter and a
whole number of other companies for
enhanced technology which now uh Haloyme
is guiding to about a billion dollar in
revenue uh in the next few years.
Remarkable story. And then from Haloyme
what was your next uh leap? Then I uh
started my own uh fund. It was a family
office fund called City Hill Ventures.
And this was the idea of found fund and
lead different uh life science
companies. So sort of took a broad view
of of the healthcare industry, did some
medical device, did some healthcare
technology, did a lot of biotech,
realized biotech really was my sweet
spot. And so uh I started a number of
companies including Eclipse Therapeutics
which was a spinout from Biogen IDC. Uh
I started Ignit uh that same year. uh
joined them full-time in 2012 when
Eclipse was acquired by Bionomics. So it
was good early proof of concept wrote an
article on it called Small Ball
Investing uh and then I ran Igniter for
many years. I then started Bonti in 2015
which was a sort of a spin out of
technology from Allergan and then both
Ignit and Bonti were acquired in 2018 uh
in the same year. So that that was a big
year for for City Hill. So let's let's
talk briefly about the Arasa story.
We're obviously fortunate to have been
uh an early thank you for being there in
the early days early stage investor in
the company. It's been remarkable to see
that the company's journey. So Arasa,
the company's tagline is erase cancer,
which is really where the name Arasa
comes from, right? Let's talk generally
about cancer and and I want to go back
and talk more about the biotechnology
industry and your your journey as an
entrepreneur. But if we just focus and
uh zoom out for a second on on the
cancer landscape, where do you think we
are in that journey? So Arasa's mission,
it's actually a port manto for with a
double meaning. So one is erase cancer,
the other is to eradicate ras driven
cancer. So that's sort of embedded in in
the uh the acronym so to speak. But I
would say we're making progress. We
definitely are not where we need to be,
but it's we're still early innings. And
I think what's really encouraging is
where we are today is significantly
better than where we were five years.
And so with every five-year increment,
we just keep making progress. So it's
just amazing to see the progress of of
imunotherapy and and just how many um
therapies we have at our disposal for
different uh solid tumor types and
liquid tumor types for that matter. uh
as you think about the uh monoconal
antibbody approaches the um even uh T-
cell therapies CARTT uh other other
aspects there there's a lot to be
excited and grateful for but I think um
what's most exciting is especially with
the checkpoint inhibitors where you see
the the long tail so you see about 20%
of patients that have long-term uh
remission that that actually turns into
into cures and I think the the goal of
the cancer fighting community has been
how do we increase that long tail? So
rather than 20% or one in five patients,
how how can we get two in five or three
in five? And so we're exploring a number
of combinations. Um but then with
targeted therapies there's some really
exciting breakthroughs whether it's the
some of the ADCs like uh in hair too
where you see just remarkable long-term
survival outcomes OS and PFS with uh in
breast cancer and and now they're in
five different indications including
tissue agnostic and I think we're
scratching the surface of the
combinations uh that that we can
explore. I put this out as a sort of a
straw man argument. One would think that
if cancer is primarily a disease of DNA,
as we've gotten better at being able to
sequence um tumors, to sequence cancer
to analyze it, um how much has that
illuminated our ability to figure out
how to target cancer, how to find its
Achilles heel. In other words, if we can
understand cancer
drivers and if most cancer drivers are
genetic in nature, can we work backwards
by analyzing the genetics of all cancer
and then come up with strategies for
targeting tumors in a way that will
actually help us uh beat cancers. Just a
few years ago, I learned about ECDNA. So
extra chromosomal DNA are these circles
that basically tumors use to harbor uh
massive anka gene amplification. And so
um most of the industry did didn't even
know that this circular chromosomeal DNA
was a mechanism for driving cancer as
well as metastases and recurrence until
Paul Michelle and others identified this
and developed diagnostics to to look for
it. And so that's some of the work that
we're doing at Boundless Bio, which I
co-founded with uh the folks over at
Arch and uh and with Paul Michelle. And
we're really excited about about that
approach of of looking at the genetic
vulnerabilities of these ECDNAs and then
using that to combine with some of the
more traditional approaches as well.
Yeah. And I think that's what's
interesting and probably also
frustrating about our field which is the
the biology as proves to be the case
again and again is is always more
complex than we originally think. Right.
Right. So we think okay we can an we can
you know sequence tumors. We'll figure
out where the mutations are. We'll
figure out how to target them. But then
we learn about things like EC uh DNA
that just obviously complicates the
picture, right? Um on the one hand in
terms of figuring out what to go after
and on the other, one of the things that
I think is reason to be optimistic, but
there's still a long way to go. as you
say, we're still scratching the surface
is we get increasingly better and um
more sophisticated in the types of tools
or or the modalities that we develop to
hit cancer with the weapons we have
against cancer that that armamentarium
that um that uh weapons um uh chest is
expanding right continues to expand and
so I think there's there's reason to
give hope if we were to flash forward 5
years from now what would be your
prediction on what what will have proven
to be the the next sort set of great
leaps forward. Well, I think we're
learning more and more. I think we're
taking new chemical modalities and
approaches to shutting down different
anka gene drivers or quote unquote
undruggable targets. So, I think the
modalities are really exciting. Even in
our own experience at Arasa, uh you
know, Revolution Medicine uh here in
town is uh a pioneer in the approach of
taking a molecular glue or cycloplin a
binder to drug RAS, which RAS in the
active GTP state has historically been
really difficult to uh to shut down, but
we were really just uh so encouraged by
their uh data uh this was about a little
more than a year ago uh regarding how
they could take uh RMC
6236 and and shut down RAS in the active
state and show responses in G12D and
other types of tumors. And so we
actually have our own uh cyclopin a
molecular glue called RAS 15 that we
just inlicensed and we're really excited
about that with even higher potency than
RMC 6236. But it's approaches like that
that I think are really moving the
needle uh whether alone or in
combination with with other approaches.
And it's what we need is to keep
advancing the standard of care. Until
Revmed showed that um that you could
target RAS wild type, I actually was
very skeptical that we'd be able to do
that. But then when I saw the data, I
was just amazed that this was safe and
reasonably well tolerated. So, it's
really exciting to see the amount of
progress that's happening with new
modalities and I think the the kinds of
things you describe like these sort of
leaps forward give us lots of reasons to
be optimistic, right? That the next 5
years and beyond are are going to
continue to evolve in a way that will
help us make great improvements in in
this field and in other disease areas as
well. Shifting gears a bit, uh what' you
do this
summer? Well, one of the highlights is
my family went on a trip to the
Galopagos Islands. So, this was uh uh
basically a Stanford travel study
program with Bill Durham, who was a
faculty member. He taught in the human
biology department at Stanford for for
decades. And uh this was on our bucket
list to to uh go on this trip and it was
just a once in a-lifetime opportunity.
And Galapagos, of course, are the
islands where Charles Darwin, that's
right, uh, sails down there and and has
the sort of Eureka realization around
around natural selection and his whole
theory is is born there. And believe it
or not, I mean, he was in his 20s. I
think he was 26 or something when he
discovered this. And uh, he was only
there for for less than a month. So
Charles Darwin goes down to Galapagos,
spends some time there and comes up with
the theory of evolution uh with the
concept of survival of the fittest. You
go down there this summer, you spend
some time in Galopagos. What theories
did you come up with? There's this bird
called the frigot. And so most birds
that that dive for fish, they have oil
glands that basically, you know, cover
their their feathers and allow them to
not sink. Now, the frigat bird has
vestigial oil glands. So, they can't do
this. If they if they fish on their own
and dive bomb, they're dead. And so,
they'll sink. They'll sink. Yeah. And
so, they've basically evolved to uh be
bigger than all the other birds. So,
when the blue-footed boobies and the
pelicans and the other birds dive bomb
and get the fish, the frigots come in
and they just take the fish away from
them. And so, they're called
kleptoarasites. But there's this whole
ecosystem of these bully birds. And do
they fight them in the air or do they
fight them on land? They fight them in
the air. So they basically just
intercept the and and take, you know,
they they basically rest the the fish
away from from the other birds. And so
that's just evolution uh at at work. And
then um you know, in terms of the the
flora, there are these trees that are
called uh scalas. They're named after
one of the scientists. And if you look
closely, the trees are they're
beautiful. They almost look like Dr.
Seuss types of trees because they're
just so exotic. Uh they're actually
daisies if you do the genetic analysis.
And so how do daisies become trees?
Well, it's again very Darwinian in terms
of um you know, herbaceous plants sort
of fighting as bushes for sunlight and
scarce resources. But these daisies just
keep growing and they grow as far as
they can and become trees just so that
they can out compete the other the other
uh plants. And so when you draw the
parallels with our industry, I mean
clearly uh you know some of the lessons
are you adapt or die. So if you don't
learn to adapt in our industry, you're
not around very very long. And last few
years I think have been sobering for all
of us, Arasa included. It's just been
really tough and very Darwinian in terms
of competition for uh you know attention
from investors, attention from partners,
attention from employees uh you know in
terms of the war for talent. So it's
just been really tough. And so you have
to adapt or die. And so we've done a lot
of uh pivoting in terms of uh
prioritizations and rep prioritizations
and trying to get access to capital and
and trying to have uh programs that that
people really care about and that can
really move the needle for patients and
then the rest takes care of itself. And
I think everyone's trying to do that.
But then it's really the realization
that um we all need to embrace change
and and embrace it not just to survive
but to thrive. So in addition to
defense, there's also offense. So at
Arasa we're focused on the RAS map
kinase pathway. Uh our lead program in
the clinic is a compound called
napleafanibib which is a panraf
inhibitor and we're super excited about
that for nras mutant melanoma but nrass
mutant melanoma there's about uh 50,000
patients total in in the US. It's
definitely an unmet need but it's not a
massive one. And so we were looking at
different programs that could really
move the needle for hundreds of
thousands of of people uh in the US and
globally. And so we were able to inlic
successfully two uh RAS targeting
programs. One is a a panas molecular
glue as I mentioned earlier and then the
other is a a krass selective pancrass
uh small molecule inhibitor. And so
we're really excited about those
programs and the ability to combine with
standard of care uh in uh pancreatic
cancer in lung cancer colon cancer other
solid tumor types and then with each
other and then if you combine it with
the molecular glue for any uh acquired
resistance mutations then that could
really be the interesting combo. If I'm
a founder, if I'm an entrepreneur to an
entrepreneur today and I'm sort of
navigating through what is a very
difficult environment, a very
inhospitable environment. Yeah. What are
some of the adaptations that I should
have front of mind? Yeah. No, I mean I
think the I would say that uh don't be
afraid to pivot and if you're going to
pivot, pivot fast. So the faster you
make the decision, the better. All the
companies I've been at, there's always
been one or multiple pivots. And so at
Arasa
uh you know we we actually have had sort
of three epics at the company. So in the
early days we were focused on discovery
for new uh RAS targeting agents and then
we sort of brought in a number of assets
and we went public as you'll recall
around the irk targeting program and
then we uh brought in uh Naple Rafanib
from Noardis and that's a really
exciting program but I think high
probability of success but in terms of
moving the needle on a massive unmet
need probably not as much and so then we
brought in uh the latest which are these
two RAS targeting agents and now the the
enthusiasm
uh amongst uh the buy side and sell side
uh is is really very high. So I think
we're we're in the the sweet spot right
now. And so it's really sort of
embracing uh the uncertainty but but
applying creativity, resilience and and
uh decisive uh action to uh to navigate
that. Yeah. And that's that I think
that's a key point right because
pivoting is daunting. So now if we look
at the landscape broadly
um it's a challenging environment for
all the reasons we've said is there a
silver lining is there anything out
there on the landscape that you'd say
look this is actually you know these are
calm seas to maybe you know head towards
uh if you're an early stage company the
answer may be no yeah no I mean I think
the pendulum always swings back and
forth between platforms and products and
back again I think we're back in the
product uh cycle where I and really
focusing on what is that product or
therapeutic that's really going to move
the needle for patients. And so there's
a number of AI companies that are really
building that drug development expertise
to take a product or products further
into the pipeline to be able to generate
the clinical data that investors and
partners want to see. So I think that's
really the playbook at this point in
this environment. And people want to see
what impact can you have on patients
whether it's uh discharging safety or
showing uh efficacy proof of concept. I
think it's really important to show what
your therapeutic can do. Um and then
it's really just marshalling the
resources uh to focus on that on what's
really going to move the needle. And by
the way, when the pendulum does go back,
raise money, but really treat it as if,
you know, you're in a in a bare market
as opposed to a bull market. So, I
think, you know, one of the things that
we did right at Arasa was when we went
public in 2021, day one after the IPO,
we said, now that we have all this
money, what are we going to do with it?
We're not going to spend it. We're
actually going to save it. And so, we we
knew that the pendulum was going to
swing back. it was going to be tougher
uh days ahead. So, we've talked about
pivots, we've talked about creativity,
we've talked about pendulum swinging. Uh
one of the most remarkable pendulum
swings, pivots, uh that encompasses
creativity, I think would apply to you.
You said at the very beginning, uh you
loved Hollywood. Um, you started your
your fund, City Hill Ventures, and you
said it primarily invested in
biotechnology
companies that is evolving, right? So
now you're invest you're investing in
things that are very much not
biotechnology companies. Very Darwinian,
isn't it? It very very much is. So talk
to me a little bit about that. Yeah. So,
uh, yeah, I was born in Montreal, grew
up in Southern California, but in 2018
when Ignit was was bought by RO, it
allowed me to take three months off. So,
I was off the grid. I put my iPhone in
the drawer. My wife got me a flip phone
with a different number. Uh, you had a
burner. I had a burner phone, sweet,
believe it or not, I still have it, but
I don't use it anymore. I just prayed. I
reflected. I spent a lot of quality time
with family, friends, traveled,
uh did a lot of creative pursuits. So I
came back in October, we hit the ground
running with Arasa, and then later that
year, I started uh a company called City
Hill Arts, which is an offshoot of City
Hill. And so the idea is to revitalize
people, planet, and perspective. It was
just this idea that can we shape
people's hearts and minds in a powerful
way with inspiring stories, hopeful
stories, stories of love, kindness,
stories that that bring people together
and unite us and show us what unites us
as opposed to divides us. And so out of
that came uh this slate of movies that
uh embody those kinds of stories. And so
we are genre agnostic, but really the
unifying theme is what unites us and and
stories with heart. So, you make movies
now? I make movies now. Yeah. So, uh I I
can't tell you how cool that is, by the
way. Thank you. No, I I I feel so
blessed to be doing what I love in terms
of the twin passions of science and
biotech and and arts in the movies. So,
I'm going to attempt to use Hollywood
industry terms, but what's on the slate
of move? What's on the slate? Is that
even how you pronounce it? Yeah, that's
it. Okay. So, what's on the slate in
terms of movies that are coming down the
pike? So, uh, the first big movie for
us, uh, is showing in theaters now. It's
called My Penguin Friend. So, it's a
story inspired by a true story between a
Brazilian fisherman that came across
this Argentinian penguin all covered in
oil. The fisherman nursed him back to
health and then every year the penguin
swam thousands of miles from Patagonia
to this fisherman's remote village in
Ilanje, Brazil. So, that happened every
year for eight years. That's the true
story. It blew up on social media in
2016 and then one of our uh producers
tracked down uh the real fisherman and
he basically got his life rights and we
cast 10 real penguins in the role of
Dindum. So about 80% of the movie is
shot with real penguins. You can't put
penguins in peril though. So 15% is with
CGI and then 5% is with puppets or
animatronics. Oh wow. Yeah. Well, first
of all, you talk about stories that
unite. you're telling the story of a
Brazilian and an Argentinian getting
along. Hey, so that's amazing in of
itself. That's a miracle, right? Um, but
that's the first and then we have
another movie, a small movie called The
Secret Art of uh human flight. So, it's
about a widowerower who is grieving and
uh he meets this guru who uh teaches him
how to fly. Oh, wow. And is that also a
true story? No, it's it's a grounded
sci-fi, but uh it's going to be a day
and dates release. uh actually this
Friday. So, uh people could see it in
the theater as well as on streaming at
the same time. Oh my goodness. Yeah, you
guys are busy. So, yeah. And then uh you
know, we've got some other uh movies
that we're working on. Is there a
comparison between the biotechnology
industry and movie making cuz at the
surface you would think these feel
pretty similar. You're you're making an
investment upfront in the hope that you
have a hit. Right. Right. which is a hit
is used both in biotech and movie
making. There's actually an uncanny uh
parallel between those two industries.
So let's say a given project in the
movie business. Uh let's take a really
successful film, you know, uh the king
speech won the Oscar.
How how many years do you think that
took to uh to make? I'm going to guess a
long time. I'm going to say 10 years.
Yeah. 13 years. My goodness. Yeah. So
they call it in in Hollywood, they call
it development hell just because it it
takes so long to get these movies made.
So in our industry, you know, it's about
8 to 10 years for a typical drug to make
it from the early beginnings to uh to
launch. And in Hollywood, it's it's no
different. I mean, there's a lot of
nonlinear paths that that these movie
projects uh take and and there's a lot
of stakeholders. Um and then the
probability of success of any given
project. So when you look at a drug, the
POSOS really uh increases by stage. It's
kind of the same in Hollywood except
that the uh outcome in terms of box
office revenue and performance is really
just imprecise. So there's no way to
know whether a given project I mean I I
love penguins. I you probably love I
don't know anyone that doesn't love
penguins, but I still have no idea how
well my penguin friend's going to do.
And so you have to take a portfolio
approach in uh you know the the film
investment uh uh arena as you do in in
biotech. So we we depend on hits. We
each have our own version of development
hell. Right. In our case it's discovery
and development hell. Is dimim still
with us? Dimn is not with us but the 10
rescue penguins are. And in fact two of
them fell in love on set. And so, uh,
yeah, they were unusable because they
would just stand back to back and stare
off hopelessly in the distance. So, we
actually had eight penguins to work
with. Well, Jonathan, I want to thank
you so much for spending time with us
today and really want to thank you more
importantly for all that you do, not
only for the magic of making movies, but
all you've done for the magic of making
medicines. Oh, thank you very much, Mar.
[Music]
